Introduction
Markov decision processes (MDPs), also known as discrete-time controlled Markov processes in the control literature, are a class of discrete-time stochastic control processes with a simple structure that makes them useful in many applications. For example, in reinforcement learning it is assumed that the underlying dynamics can be modeled using MDPs. This blog post isn’t about the applications though, but rather about the more technical existence and uniqueness questions — questions which are often ignored. We will start with carefully defining the Markov decision process and then show two intuitive results.
In an MDP there is an underlying discrete-time Markov process whose trajectory can be influenced by a decision maker by choosing actions from a pre-specified class of admissible actions. The goal is choose actions in such a way so as to optimize a performance criterion. The state of the system at time n+1n+1n+1﻿ then depends, in a Markovian way, on the state of the system and the action chosen at time n.n.n.﻿ Depending on how general the state spaces and action space are, this framework can model a wide variety of interesting problems.
Let us discuss a toy problem—inventory control problem—for motivation. You are the manager of a distribution centre which sells the product to shops and buys the product in bulk from a factory. Suppose the maximum capacity of the distribution centre is CCC﻿ units, and therefore the state space is S=[0,C],\mathsf S = [0, C],S=[0,C],﻿ i.e., the state of the distribution centre at time nnn﻿ is a random variable XnX_nXn​﻿ taking values in S.\mathsf S.S.﻿ The action that you can take is order some quantity of product from the factory. The action space A\mathsf AA﻿ also equals [0,C][0,C][0,C]﻿. At time nnn﻿ you can observe the state XnX_nXn​﻿ of the system, and with a policy in mind you order AnA_nAn​﻿ units from the factory. Of course, AnA_nAn​﻿ must take values in [0,C−Xn][0, C-X_n][0,C−Xn​]﻿. The demand from the shops is given by the i.i.d. random variables {ξn}n≥0\{\xi_n\}_{n \ge 0}{ξn​}n≥0​﻿ with a common distribution μ\muμ﻿ on S.\mathsf S.S.﻿ It costs hhh﻿ dollars per unit of product to hold the product, bbb﻿ dollars per unit of product to buy the product, and earns sss﻿ dollars per unit of product to sell the product. Any unmet demand is simply lost revenue. How should you choose a policy π={An}n=0N\pi = \{A_n\}_{n=0}^Nπ={An​}n=0N​﻿ to maximize the revenue over, say, NNN﻿ days?
Let us write the model more precisely. Suppose on day 000﻿ you start with X0=x0X_0 = x_0X0​=x0​﻿ units of product, which is a constant. Then we have
Xn+1=max⁡{0,Xn+An−ξn}=:f(Xn,An,ξn),0≤n<N.X_{n+1} = \max\{0, X_{n}+A_{n}-\xi_{n}\} =: f(X_{n}, A_{n}, \xi_{n}), \quad 0 \le n < N.Xn+1​=max{0,Xn​+An​−ξn​}=:f(Xn​,An​,ξn​),0≤n<N.
The revenue on day nnn﻿ is
Rn=smin⁡{ξn,Xn}−bAn−hXn,0≤n≤N.R_n = s \min\{\xi_n, X_n\} - b A_n - h X_n, \quad 0 \le n \le N.Rn​=smin{ξn​,Xn​}−bAn​−hXn​,0≤n≤N.
The total expected revenue is
JN(π,x0)=E[∑n=1NRn].J_N(\pi, x_0) = \mathbb E \left[ \sum_{n=1}^N R_n \right].JN​(π,x0​)=E[n=1∑N​Rn​].
Does there exist an admissible policy π∗\pi^*π∗﻿ such that it maximises the total expected revenue? That is,
JN(π∗,x0)=sup⁡πJN(π,x0).J_N(\pi^*, x_0) = \sup_{\pi} J_N(\pi, x_0).JN​(π∗,x0​)=πsup​JN​(π,x0​).
Is π∗\pi^*π∗﻿ optimal for every starting state x0x_0x0​﻿? It will be more convenient to model the transition dynamics of such a model using stochastic kernels, which informally model the transition probabilities of the process. That is, we want to find a stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from S×A\mathsf S \times \mathsf AS×A﻿ to S\mathsf SS﻿ which gives the probability of the state at day n+1n+1n+1﻿ being in B⊆SB \subseteq \mathsf SB⊆S﻿ given that on day nnn﻿ the state was XnX_{n}Xn​﻿ and we took action AnA_nAn​﻿. We can do this as follows
κ((Xn,An),B)=μ({s∈S:f(Xn,An,s)∈B}).\kappa((X_n,A_n), B) = \mu(\{s \in \mathsf S : f(X_n,A_n,s) \in B\}).κ((Xn​,An​),B)=μ({s∈S:f(Xn​,An​,s)∈B}).
We haven’t been very precise about our formulation. To this end, let us start by defining the objects like stochastic kernels and sets which will define our action and state spaces.
Setting the Stage
I had initially intended for this section to be a small one, but as I wrote I couldn’t help but go on a ramble as it helped me learn. If you are already comfortable with the notions of standard Borel spaces, stochastic kernels (also known as Markov kernels or transition probability kernels) and regular conditional distributions, or if you don’t want to be fully rigorous and are okay with understanding the core ideas without bothering too much with rigour and notation, feel free to skip directly to the section on Markov Decision Process.
Note on notation: I will be using sans serif typestyle for spaces, for example S,T,A\mathsf{S}, \mathsf{T}, \mathsf{A}S,T,A﻿ etc., and script typestyle for σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebras, for example, S,T,A\mathscr{S}, \mathscr{T}, \mathscr{A}S,T,A﻿ etc. In this section I will be fastidiously careful about writing the σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra, but starting from the next section on Markov Decision Processes I often won’t write the σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra explicitly because we will dealing with topological spaces and Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra is to be assumed implicit. But if I am forced to write, then I’ll use the script typestyle of the letter to denote the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra of the space written in sans serif typestyle of the corresponding letter; for example, A\mathscr{A}A﻿ for A.\mathsf A.A.﻿ We denote the vector space of measurable functions from (X,X)(\mathsf X, \mathscr X)(X,X)﻿ to R\RR﻿ by X\mathscr XX﻿ — the context will make it clear if we are referring to a function or a set, and what the domain of the function is. We denote the cone (i.e., stable under sums and multiplication by positive constants) of measurable functions from (X,X)(\mathsf X, \mathscr X)(X,X)﻿ to [0,+∞][0, +\infty][0,+∞]﻿ by X+.\mathscr X_+.X+​.﻿
Standard Borel Space
I discussed the notion of standard Borel spaces in the blog post on conditional probability, but since they play an important role in our discussion on Markov decision processes, let me elaborate on them a bit more here. Standard Borel spaces are usually studied under the banner of descriptive set theory and are intimately connected with other descriptive set theoretic concepts like analytic spaces, Lusin spaces and Souslin spaces. We will not focus on this side of the standard Borel spaces though, but rather on some important probabilistic results that can be formulated at this level of generality.
Generally speaking, very few meaningful statements can be made about Markov decision processes when we impose no regularity structure on the spaces involved and let them be any measurable spaces. This is where standard Borel spaces come in — powerful results can be concluded with this structure, and yet they are sufficiently general to be satisfying.
Polish Space
Let us start by recalling Polish spaces.
Definition 1: A Polish space is a separable, completely metrizable topological space.
Examples
Any set with the discrete topology is completely metrizable, and therefore if it is countable it is Polish. So, for example, {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1}﻿, N\NN﻿ and Z\ZZ﻿, each with the discrete topology, are Polish.
Rn\R^nRn﻿ with the usual topology is Polish, for each n∈N.n \in \N.n∈N.﻿
The topology of any (real or complex) Banach space is completely metrizable, and therefore separable Banach spaces are Polish.
The completion of a separable metric space is Polish.
Any closed subspace of a Polish space is Polish.
The disjoint union of countably many Polish spaces is Polish.
The product of countably many Polish spaces is Polish.
All of these examples follow from elementary properties of metric spaces. So, for example, to show the last example, first show that the product of countably many separable metric spaces is itself separable using the definition of product topology, and then show that the product of countably many complete metric spaces is itself a complete metric space using the idea of the product metric and the definition of Cauchy sequences.
Polish spaces are the probabilist’s favourite spaces to work with since they are simple to deal with and a lot of spaces are Polish, while almost all results that hold in R\RR﻿ still hold in a Polish space. For example, if (X,dX)(\mathsf X,d_{\mathsf X})(X,dX​)﻿ is a compact metric space and (Y,dY)(\mathsf Y, d_{\mathsf Y})(Y,dY​)﻿ is Polish, then C(X,Y)C(\mathsf X,\mathsf Y)C(X,Y)﻿, the set of continuous functions from X\mathsf XX﻿ to Y\mathsf YY﻿ with the uniform metric d(f,g)=sup⁡x∈XdY(f(x),g(y))d(f,g) = \sup_{x \in \mathsf X} d_{\mathsf Y}(f(x), g(y))d(f,g)=supx∈X​dY​(f(x),g(y))﻿, is Polish.
Standard Borel Space
Recall the notion of isomorphism between algebraic objects or the notion of homeomorphism between topological spaces. Both these notions give a bijective correspondence between two objects that preserves the algebraic or the topological structure. In a similar spirit we have the notion of isomorphism between two measurable spaces.
Definition 2 [Isomorphism and Borel isomorphism]: Two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ are called isomorphic iff there is a bijective function f ⁣:S→Tf \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf Tf:S→T﻿ such that both fff﻿ and its inverse f−1f^{-1}f−1﻿ are measurable. The function fff﻿ is called an isomorphism. In the special case where S\mathsf SS﻿ and T\mathsf TT﻿ are topological spaces equipped with their Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebras and f ⁣:S→Tf \colon \mathsf S \to \mathsf Tf:S→T﻿ is an isomorphism, fff﻿ is called a Borel isomorphism, and S\mathsf SS﻿ and T\mathsf TT﻿ are called Borel isomorphic.
Definition 3 [Standard Borel space]: A standard Borel space is a measurable space isomorphic to a Polish space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra.
Let me list some properties about standard Borel spaces without proof—mostly to justify using them as our default spaces.
Proposition 1: The product of countably many standard Borel spaces is a standard Borel space.
Proposition 2: A measurable subset S\mathsf SS﻿ of a standard Borel space (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr T)(T,T)﻿, where we endow S\mathsf SS﻿ with the σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra S={T∩S : T∈T}\mathscr S = \{ T \cap \mathsf S \,: \, T \in \mathscr T\}S={T∩S:T∈T}﻿, is a standard Borel space. For the other direction, if S\mathsf SS﻿ is a metrizable topological space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra S\mathscr SS﻿, then (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ is a standard Borel space if and only if S\mathsf SS﻿ is homeomorphic to a Borel subset of a Polish space.
It is obvious from the definition that two countable metrizable spaces are Borel isomorphic if and only if they have the same cardinality. For the uncountable case, it is not immediately obvious when two spaces are Borel isomorphic. The next proposition is a deep and surprising result.
Proposition 3: All uncountable standard Borel spaces are mutually isomorphic.
Observe that [0,1][0,1][0,1]﻿ endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra is a Polish space, and therefore every uncountable standard Borel space is isomorphic to ([0,1],B([0,1])),([0,1], \mathscr{B}([0,1])),([0,1],B([0,1])),﻿ where the notation B(T)\mathscr B(\mathsf T)B(T)﻿ denotes the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra of a topological space T.\mathsf T.T.﻿ This observation will prove to be very helpful in proving existence result for regular conditional distributions, in proving the disintegration theorem etc.
Proposition 4: If a bijective map between standard Borel spaces is measurable, then the inverse map is also measurable.
This, in particular, implies that if both (S,S1)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S_1)(S,S1​)﻿ and (S,S2)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S_2)(S,S2​)﻿ are standard Borel spaces, then S1=S2.\mathscr S_1 = \mathscr S_2.S1​=S2​.﻿ Now recall that the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra on [0,1][0,1][0,1]﻿ is a strict subset of the Lebesgue σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra on it. This gives us a simple example of a measurable space which is not a standard Borel space.
A very useful result that further justifies the case for using standard Borel spaces is the following: Let (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ be a standard Borel space and let P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathsf S)P(S)﻿ denote the collection of all probability measures on (S,S).(\mathsf S, \mathscr S).(S,S).﻿ Endow P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathsf S)P(S)﻿ with the topology of weak convergence, i.e., the topology generated by the evaluation maps P(S)∋μ↦μ(S)∈[0,1]\mathcal{P}(\mathsf S) \ni\mu \mapsto \mu(S) \in [0,1]P(S)∋μ↦μ(S)∈[0,1]﻿, where SSS﻿ varies over S\mathscr SS﻿ (or equivalently, by the maps μ↦∫f dμ\mu \mapsto \int f \, \mathrm{d}\muμ↦∫fdμ﻿, where fff﻿ varies over Cb(S)C_b(\mathsf S)Cb​(S)﻿). Then P(S)\mathcal{P}(\mathsf S)P(S)﻿ equipped with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra is a standard Borel space. This fact becomes useful when dealing with partially observable MDPs. Here a standard approach is to transform them into an equivalent “completely observable” MDP (the one in Definition ? ahead) with a larger state space, a space of probability measures.
A cool fact, which has no bearing on our discussion ahead, is the following.
Proposition 5: If (X,X)(\mathsf X, \mathscr X)(X,X)﻿ and (Y,Y)(\mathsf Y, \mathscr Y)(Y,Y)﻿ are two standard Borel spaces, then the map f ⁣:X→Yf \colon \mathsf X \to \mathsf Yf:X→Y﻿ is measurable if and only if its graph ⟦f⟧:={(x,f(x)) : x∈X}\llbracket f \rrbracket := \{(x, f(x)) \,:\, x \in \mathsf X\}[[f]]:={(x,f(x)):x∈X}﻿ is a measurable subset of the product space (X×Y,X⊗Y).(\mathsf X \times \mathsf Y, \mathscr X \otimes \mathscr Y).(X×Y,X⊗Y).﻿
Stochastic Kernels
Suppose that a particle is moving randomly in a state space given by a measurable space (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿. We would like to be able to know the probability, denoted with say κ(x,B)\kappa(x, B)κ(x,B)﻿, of the particle finding itself in a set B∈SB \in \mathscr{S}B∈S﻿ after a unit of time given that it started at state x∈S.x \in \mathsf S.x∈S.﻿ Stochastic kernels model this notion of transition probabilities in a natural manner and we will rely heavily on them in our discussion.
Definition 4: Let (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ be two measurable spaces. A map
κ ⁣:S×T→[0,1]\begin{equation*} \kappa \colon \mathsf S \times \mathscr{T} \to [0,1] \end{equation*}κ:S×T→[0,1]​
is called a stochastic kernel or a Markov kernel or a transition probability kernel from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ — or, briefly, from S\mathsf SS﻿ to T\mathsf TT﻿ — if
x↦κ(x,B)x \mapsto \kappa(x, B)x↦κ(x,B)﻿ is S−\mathscr{S}-S−﻿measurable for each B∈TB \in \mathscr{T}B∈T﻿, and
B↦κ(x,B)B \mapsto \kappa(x,B)B↦κ(x,B)﻿ is a probability measure on (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ for each x∈S.x \in \mathsf S.x∈S.﻿
We often denote κ(x,B)\kappa(x, B)κ(x,B)﻿ with κx(B)\kappa_x(B)κx​(B)﻿ and the mapping x↦κ(x,B)x \mapsto \kappa(x, B)x↦κ(x,B)﻿ with κ(B).\kappa(B).κ(B).﻿ If (T,T)=(S,S)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T}) = (\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(T,T)=(S,S)﻿, we simply say a kernel on (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ or, even more simply, on S\mathsf SS﻿. Instead of saying a stochastic kernel from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T),(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T}),(T,T),﻿ some books and papers say a stochastic kernel on (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ given (S,S).(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S}).(S,S).﻿ We can view the stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ as a measurable function from S\mathsf SS﻿ to the space P(T)\mathcal{P}(\mathsf T)P(T)﻿ of probability measures on (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿, where the σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra on P(T)\mathcal{P}(\mathsf T)P(T)﻿ is generated by the weak topology, as mentioned above. For this reason, stochastic kernel are also called random probability measures. We can also view the stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ as a probabilistic generalization of the concept of function from S\mathsf SS﻿ to T\mathsf TT﻿ — instead of associating with each x∈Sx \in \mathsf Sx∈S﻿ a unique value from T\mathsf TT﻿, we associate a probability distribution on T.\mathsf T.T.﻿
The term kernel, without the adjective stochastic, will be used to denote a similar object as a stochastic kernel except that the property 2 in the definition above state B↦κ(x,B)B \mapsto \kappa(x,B)B↦κ(x,B)﻿ is a measure on (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ for each x∈S.x \in \mathsf S.x∈S.﻿
Examples
Given a measurable space (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿, the function
S×S∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B)={1if x∈B,0if x∈S∖B\mathsf S \times \mathscr{S} \ni (x,B) \mapsto \kappa(x,B) = \begin{cases} 1 &\text{if } x \in B, \\ 0 &\text{if } x \in \mathsf S \setminus B \end{cases}S×S∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B)={10​if x∈B,if x∈S∖B​
defines a stochastic kernel on (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿, called the unit kernel. For each x∈Sx \in \mathsf Sx∈S﻿, the measure B↦κ(x,B)B \mapsto \kappa(x,B)B↦κ(x,B)﻿ is the Dirac measure δx\delta_xδx​﻿ on (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ at x.x.x.﻿
Given two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ and a measure ν\nuν﻿ on (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿, the function
S×T∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B):=ν(B)\mathsf S \times \mathscr{T} \ni (x,B) \mapsto \kappa(x, B) := \nu(B)S×T∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B):=ν(B)
defines a kernel from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ which does not depend on x.x.x.﻿ Therefore, every measure can be seen as a special type of a kernel.
Given two measurable spaces (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ and a measurable function f ⁣:S→Tf \colon \mathsf{S} \to \mathsf Tf:S→T﻿, the function
S×T∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B):=1B(f(x))\mathsf S \times \mathscr T \ni (x,B) \mapsto \kappa(x,B) := \mathbf{1}_B(f(x))S×T∋(x,B)↦κ(x,B):=1B​(f(x))
defines a stochastic kernel from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T).(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T}).(T,T).﻿
Consider the two measurable spaces (S={1,2,…,n},P(S))(\mathsf S = \{1, 2, \ldots, n\}, \mathfrak{P}(\mathsf S))(S={1,2,…,n},P(S))﻿ and (T={1,2,…,m},P(T))(\mathsf T = \{1, 2, \ldots, m\}, \mathfrak{P}(\mathsf T))(T={1,2,…,m},P(T))﻿ for two positive integers nnn﻿ and mmm﻿, with P(X)\mathfrak{P}(\mathsf X)P(X)﻿ denoting the power set of a set X.\mathsf X.X.﻿ Suppose we are given an n×mn \times mn×m﻿ matrix K\mathbf KK﻿ containing non-negative elements such that the sum along each row is 1.1.1.﻿ Then the function κ\kappaκ﻿ defined by
S×P(T)∋(i,B)↦κ(i,B):=∑j∈BKi,j\mathsf S \times \mathfrak{P}(\mathsf T) \ni (i,B) \mapsto \kappa(i, B) := \sum_{j \in B} \mathbf K_{i,j}S×P(T)∋(i,B)↦κ(i,B):=j∈B∑​Ki,j​
is a stochastic kernel from S\mathsf SS﻿ to T.\mathsf T.T.﻿ The case where S\mathsf SS﻿ or T\mathsf TT﻿ are countably infinite is similar.
Regular Conditional Distribution
In most discussions of MDPs the notion of conditional distribution and the associated notation are left frustratingly ambiguous. We will instead choose to simplify through abstraction. To remedy this let us spend some time discussing regular conditional distribution and disintegration in this subsection and the next. I also discussed the idea of regular conditional distribution in a previous blog post.
Let us start with a well-known but important result.
Lemma 1 [Doob-Dynkin factorization lemma]: Let (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathscr{F})(Ω,F)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr T)(T,T)﻿ be arbitrary measurable spaces, and (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ be a standard Borel space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra. Let f ⁣:Ω→Sf \colon \Omega \to \mathsf Sf:Ω→S﻿ and g ⁣:Ω→Tg \colon \Omega \to \mathsf Tg:Ω→T﻿ be measurable functions. Then fff﻿ is σ(g)−\sigma(g)-σ(g)−﻿measurable if and only if f=h∘gf = h \circ gf=h∘g﻿ for some measurable function h ⁣:T→S.h \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf S.h:T→S.﻿
Proof:
The sufficiency is very easy to verify. Indeed, if f=h∘gf = h \circ gf=h∘g﻿ for some measurable function h ⁣:T→S,h \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf S,h:T→S,﻿ then for any S∈SS \in \mathscr SS∈S﻿ we have f−1(S)=g−1(h−1(S))∈σ(g).f^{-1}(S) = g^{-1}(h^{-1}(S)) \in \sigma(g).f−1(S)=g−1(h−1(S))∈σ(g).﻿
For the necessity, we first prove the lemma for the case S=[0,1].\mathsf S = [0,1].S=[0,1].﻿ Then using Propositions 2 and 3 we will extend the argument to an arbitrary standard Borel space. This is the typical way to deal with standard Borel spaces.
So suppose that S=[0,1].\mathsf S = [0,1].S=[0,1].﻿ If f=1Af = \mathbf{1}_Af=1A​﻿ for A∈σ(g),A \in \sigma(g),A∈σ(g),﻿ then by the definition of σ(g)\sigma(g)σ(g)﻿ there exists a set B∈TB \in \mathscr{T}B∈T﻿ such that A=g−1(B).A = g^{-1}(B).A=g−1(B).﻿ Then we can write f=1B∘g,f = \mathbf{1}_B \circ g,f=1B​∘g,﻿ where 1B ⁣:T→S\mathbf{1}_B \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf S1B​:T→S﻿ is of course measurable. Linearity allows us to deduce our desired conclusion for the case when fff﻿ is a simple function. For a general σ(g)−\sigma(g)-σ(g)−﻿measurable f,f,f,﻿ we know that we can find a sequence {fn}\{f_n\}{fn​}﻿ of nonnegative simple σ(g)−\sigma(g)-σ(g)−﻿measurable functions with fn↑f.f_n \uparrow f.fn​↑f.﻿ Therefore, for each nnn﻿ we may choose measurable hn ⁣:T→Sh_n \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf Shn​:T→S﻿ such that fn=hn∘g.f_n = h_n \circ g.fn​=hn​∘g.﻿ Then h:=sup⁡nhnh := \sup_n h_nh:=supn​hn​﻿ is again measurable, and we have
f=sup⁡nfn=sup⁡n(hn∘g)=(sup⁡nhn)∘g=h∘g.f = \sup_n f_n = \sup_n (h_n \circ g) = \left(\sup_n h_n\right) \circ g = h \circ g.f=nsup​fn​=nsup​(hn​∘g)=(nsup​hn​)∘g=h∘g.
Finally, we extend the proof to the general case of S\mathsf SS﻿ being a standard Borel space. Propositions 2 and 3 imply that there exists an isomorphism ι ⁣:S→[0,1].\iota \colon \mathsf S \to [0,1].ι:S→[0,1].﻿ The preceding argument applied to the σ(g)−\sigma(g)-σ(g)−﻿measurable function ι∘f ⁣:Ω→[0,1]\iota \circ f \colon \Omega \to [0,1]ι∘f:Ω→[0,1]﻿ implies that there exists a measurable function hι ⁣:T→[0,1]h_\iota \colon \mathsf T \to [0,1]hι​:T→[0,1]﻿ such that ι∘f=hι∘g.\iota \circ f = h_\iota \circ g.ι∘f=hι​∘g.﻿ But since ι\iotaι﻿ is a bijection, we can write f=(ι−1∘hι)∘g.f = (\iota^{-1} \circ h_\iota) \circ g.f=(ι−1∘hι​)∘g.﻿ The function h:=ι−1∘hι ⁣:T→Sh := \iota^{-1} \circ h_\iota \colon \mathsf T \to \mathsf Sh:=ι−1∘hι​:T→S﻿ is our desired measurable function. □\square□﻿
Under the setting of the above lemma, suppose X ⁣:Ω→[0,∞]X \colon \Omega \to [0, \infty]X:Ω→[0,∞]﻿ is a random variable and Y ⁣:Ω→TY \colon \Omega \to \mathsf TY:Ω→T﻿ is a measurable function. Then the lemma above implies that the conditional expectation E[X∣Y]\mathbb{E}[X \mid Y]E[X∣Y]﻿ can be written as h∘Yh \circ Yh∘Y﻿ for some measurable h ⁣:T→[0,∞].h \colon \mathsf T \to [0, \infty].h:T→[0,∞].﻿
Notation: We use E[X∣Y=y]\mathbb{E}[X \mid Y=y]E[X∣Y=y]﻿ to denote h(y).h(y).h(y).﻿
Here the non-negativity of XXX﻿ is inessential, except for ensuring that the conditional expectation exists—we could have assumed XXX﻿ to be real-valued and integrable.
Regular Conditional Probability
Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb P)(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space and G\mathscr GG﻿ be a sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of F.\mathscr F.F.﻿ For A∈F,A \in \mathscr F,A∈F,﻿ if we denote with κ(A)\kappa(A)κ(A)﻿ a version of the conditional probability P(A∣G),\mathbb{P}(A \mid \mathscr G),P(A∣G),﻿ and use κω(A)\kappa_\omega(A)κω​(A)﻿ to denote κ(A)(ω),\kappa(A)(\omega),κ(A)(ω),﻿ then we have
κ(∅)=0\kappa(\varnothing) = 0κ(∅)=0﻿ a.s.;
κ(Ω)=1\kappa(\Omega) = 1κ(Ω)=1﻿ a.s.;
the mapping ω↦κω(A)\omega \mapsto \kappa_\omega(A)ω↦κω​(A)﻿ is G−\mathscr G-G−﻿measurable for each A∈FA \in \mathscr FA∈F﻿; and
by the monotone convergence theorem for conditional expectations, for every disjointed sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​}﻿ in F,\mathscr F,F,﻿
κω(⋃nAn)=∑nκω(An)\kappa_\omega\left( \bigcup_n A_n \right) = \sum_n \kappa_\omega(A_n)κω​(n⋃​An​)=n∑​κω​(An​)
for every ω\omegaω﻿ outside a null set.
With these properties the function (ω,A)↦κω(A)(\omega, A) \mapsto \kappa_\omega(A)(ω,A)↦κω​(A)﻿ looks very much like a stochastic kernel. But the fact that the null set in property 4 depends on the sequence {An}\{A_n\}{An​}﻿ and that there could be uncountably many such sequences, means that κ\kappaκ﻿ is, in general, not a stochastic kernel. When κ\kappaκ﻿ can be made into a stochastic kernel we get a very special object called a regular version of the conditional probability, or simply regular conditional probability.
Definition 5: Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb P)(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space and G\mathscr GG﻿ be a sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of F.\mathscr F.F.﻿ For A∈FA \in \mathscr FA∈F﻿ let κ(A)\kappa(A)κ(A)﻿ be a version of the conditional probability P(A∣G).\mathbb{P}(A \mid \mathscr G).P(A∣G).﻿ Then Ω×F∋(ω,A)↦κω(A)∈[0,1]\Omega \times \mathscr F \ni (\omega, A) \mapsto \kappa_\omega(A) \in [0,1]Ω×F∋(ω,A)↦κω​(A)∈[0,1]﻿ is said to be a regular version of the conditional probability P(⋅∣G)\mathbb{P}(\cdot \mid \mathscr G)P(⋅∣G)﻿ if it is a stochastic kernel from (Ω,G)(\Omega , \mathscr G)(Ω,G)﻿ to (Ω,F).(\Omega, \mathscr F).(Ω,F).﻿
Recall Theorem 2 from a previous blog post which I state here again:
Proposition 6: Under the setting of Definition 5, if XXX﻿ is a real-valued random variable whose expectation exists, then
ω↦∫ΩX dκω\omega \mapsto \int_\Omega X \, \mathrm{d}\kappa_\omegaω↦∫Ω​Xdκω​
is a version of the conditional expectation E[X∣G].\mathbb{E}\left[ X \mid \mathscr G \right].E[X∣G].﻿
When does a regular conditional probability exist? Intuitively, we need to impose conditions on either the sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra G\mathscr GG﻿ or on the probability space (Ω,F,P).(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb P).(Ω,F,P).﻿ In the first case, suppose G\mathscr GG﻿ is generated by a countable partition {An}\{A_n\}{An​}﻿ of Ω,\Omega,Ω,﻿ which is the case when G\mathscr GG﻿ is generated by a random variable taking values in a countable space. Then define
κω(A)=∑nPAn(A)  1An(ω),ω∈Ω, A∈F,\kappa_\omega(A) = \sum_n \mathbb{P}_{A_n}(A) \;\mathbf{1}_{A_n}(\omega), \quad \omega \in \Omega, \, A \in \mathscr F,κω​(A)=n∑​PAn​​(A)1An​​(ω),ω∈Ω,A∈F,
where PB(A)\mathbb{P}_B(A)PB​(A)﻿ is defined to be any number in [0,1][0,1][0,1]﻿ satisfying P(A∩B)=P(B) PB(A).\mathbb{P}(A \cap B) = \mathbb{P}(B)\, \mathbb{P}_B(A).P(A∩B)=P(B)PB​(A).﻿ This makes κ\kappaκ﻿ a regular conditional probability because A↦PB(A)A \mapsto \mathbb{P}_B(A)A↦PB​(A)﻿ is a probability measure.
For the case where G\mathscr{G}G﻿ could be arbitrary, we have the following result.
Theorem 1: If (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathscr{F})(Ω,F)﻿ is a standard Borel space, then a regular version of the conditional probability P(⋅∣G)\mathbb{P}(\cdot \mid \mathscr G)P(⋅∣G)﻿ as in Definition 5 exists.
The proof of this theorem will be a simple consequence of the existence of regular conditional distributions which we discuss next.
Regular Conditional Distribution
Definition 6: Let (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathscr{F}, \mathbb P)(Ω,F,P)﻿ be a probability space, G\mathscr GG﻿ be a sub-σ\sigmaσ﻿-algebra of F,\mathscr F,F,﻿ (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ be a measurable space, and X ⁣:Ω→SX \colon \Omega \to \mathsf SX:Ω→S﻿ be a random element. The regular conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given G\mathscr GG﻿, or simply, conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given G\mathscr GG﻿ is any stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from (Ω,G)(\Omega, \mathscr G)(Ω,G)﻿ to (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ such that
κ(B)=P({X∈B}∣G) a.s.,B∈S.(R1)\kappa(B) = \mathbb{P}(\{X \in B\} \mid \mathscr G) \text{ a.s.}, \quad B \in \mathscr S. \tag{R1}κ(B)=P({X∈B}∣G) a.s.,B∈S.(R1)
Theorem 2: Under the setting of Definition 6, if (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr S)(S,S)﻿ is a standard Borel space, then there exists a version of the regular conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given G.\mathscr G.G.﻿
Proof: [From Cinlar Theorem IV.2.10 [3]]

We shall construct the regular conditional distribution κ\kappaκ﻿ of XXX﻿ given G\mathscr GG﻿ from these countably many random variables {Cq}q∈Q.\{C_q\}_{q \in \mathbb Q}.{Cq​}q∈Q​.﻿
For q<r,q < r,q<r,﻿ we have {X≤q}⊆{X≤r},\{X \le q \} \subseteq \{X \le r\},{X≤q}⊆{X≤r},﻿ and therefore by the monotonicity of conditional expectations the event

is an almost sure event and is in G.\mathscr G.G.﻿ Then the countable intersection
Ω0=⋂q<rq,r∈QΩqr\Omega_0 = \bigcap_{\stackrel{q,r \in \mathbb Q}{q < r}} \Omega_{qr}Ω0​=q<rq,r∈Q​⋂​Ωqr​
is also an almost sure event and is in G.\mathscr G.G.﻿ Fix an arbitrary ω0∈Ω0.\omega_0 \in \Omega_0.ω0​∈Ω0​.﻿ Then the mapping

is non-decreasing, and thus, for each t∈R,t \in \R,t∈R,﻿ we can define

The resulting extension R∋t↦Ct(ω0)∈[0,1]\mathbb{R} \ni t \mapsto C_t(\omega_0) \in [0,1]R∋t↦Ct​(ω0​)∈[0,1]﻿ is non-decreasing, right-continuous, and satisfies lim⁡t→−∞Ct(ω0)=0\lim_{t \to -\infty} C_t(\omega_0) = 0limt→−∞​Ct​(ω0​)=0﻿ and lim⁡t→∞Ct(ω0)=1,\lim_{t \to \infty} C_t(\omega_0) = 1,limt→∞​Ct​(ω0​)=1,﻿ and therefore is a probability distribution function. We will use Dynkin’s theorem (Theorem 4 here), which is a type of monotone class argument. Consider the collection
D={B∈S  :  ω↦κω(B) is G-measurable}.\mathscr D = \left\{B \in \mathscr S \; : \; \omega \mapsto \kappa_\omega(B) \text{ is } \mathscr G\text{-measurable}\right\}.D={B∈S:ω↦κω​(B) is G-measurable}.
κω(S)=1\kappa_\omega(\mathsf S) = 1κω​(S)=1﻿ for all ω∈Ω\omega \in \Omegaω∈Ω﻿ and therefore ω↦κω(S)\omega \mapsto \kappa_\omega(\mathsf S)ω↦κω​(S)﻿ is G−\mathscr G-G−﻿measurable, showing S∈D.\mathsf S \in \mathscr D.S∈D.﻿ For A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B﻿ with A,B∈S,A, B \in \mathscr S,A,B∈S,﻿ we have κω(B∖A)=κω(B)−κω(A),\kappa_\omega(B \setminus A) = \kappa_\omega(B) - \kappa_\omega(A),κω​(B∖A)=κω​(B)−κω​(A),﻿ and therefore if AAA﻿ and BBB﻿ are in D\mathscr DD﻿ with A⊆BA \subseteq BA⊆B﻿ then so does B∖A.B \setminus A.B∖A.﻿ Finally, if B1⊆B2⊆⋯B_1 \subseteq B_2 \subseteq \cdotsB1​⊆B2​⊆⋯﻿ is an increasing sequence in D,\mathscr D,D,﻿ then using the continuity of measure from below and the fact that the pointwise limit of measurable functions is again measurable, we get that ⋃nBn∈D.\bigcup_n B_n \in \mathscr D.⋃n​Bn​∈D.﻿ We conclude that D\mathscr DD﻿ is a d-system.
By the Dynkin’s theorem, to show that D=S,\mathscr D = \mathscr S,D=S,﻿ it is enough to show that D\mathscr DD﻿ contains the π\piπ﻿-system {[−∞,t]  :  t∈R‾}.\{[-\infty, t] \;:\; t \in \overline\R\}.{[−∞,t]:t∈R}.﻿ For t=+∞t = +\inftyt=+∞﻿ we have already shown that [−∞,t]∈D.[-\infty, t] \in \mathscr D.[−∞,t]∈D.﻿ Similarly it is easy to see that for t=−∞t = -\inftyt=−∞﻿ we have [−∞,t]=∅∈D.[-\infty, t] = \varnothing \in \mathscr D.[−∞,t]=∅∈D.﻿ Fix a t∈Rt \in \Rt∈R﻿ and note that we can write

This implies (1)(1)(1)﻿.
This completes the proof for the special case when S=R‾.\mathsf S = \overline{\R}.S=R.﻿ To extend the proof to arbitrary standard Borel spaces, suppose ι ⁣:S→[0,1]\iota \colon \mathsf S \to [0,1]ι:S→[0,1]﻿ is an isomorphism. Here ι(B)\iota(B)ι(B)﻿ is the image of BBB﻿ under ι.\iota.ι.﻿ It is easy to check that κ\kappaκ﻿ is a stochastic kernel from (Ω,G)(\Omega, \mathscr G)(Ω,G)﻿ to (S,S).(\mathsf S, \mathscr S).(S,S).﻿ To verify property (R1)\text{(R1)}(R1)﻿ observe that, for G∈GG \in \mathscr GG∈G﻿ and B∈S,B \in \mathscr S,B∈S,﻿
P(G∩{X∈B})=P(G∩{ι∘X∈ι(B)})=∫Gκι(ι(B)) dP=∫Gκ(B) dP.□\mathbb{P}(G \cap \{X \in B\}) = \mathbb{P}(G \cap \{\iota \circ X \in \iota(B)\}) = \int_G \kappa^\iota(\iota(B)) \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P} = \int_G \kappa(B) \, \mathrm{d}\mathbb{P}. \quad\squareP(G∩{X∈B})=P(G∩{ι∘X∈ι(B)})=∫G​κι(ι(B))dP=∫G​κ(B)dP.□
Regular conditional probabilities and regular conditional distributions are closely related. If κ\kappaκ﻿ is a regular version of the conditional probability P(⋅∣G),\mathbb{P}(\cdot \mid \mathscr G),P(⋅∣G),﻿ then κX\kappa^XκX﻿ defined as
κωX(B):=κω({X∈B})\kappa_\omega^X(B) := \kappa_\omega(\{X \in B\})κωX​(B):=κω​({X∈B})
is easily seen to be a regular conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given G.\mathscr G.G.﻿ On the other hand, Theorem 1 follows from Theorem 2. Suppose that (Ω,F)(\Omega, \mathscr F)(Ω,F)﻿ is a standard Borel space and let (S,S)=(Ω,F).(\mathsf S, \mathscr S) = (\Omega, \mathscr F).(S,S)=(Ω,F).﻿ Define X(ω)=ωX(\omega) = \omegaX(ω)=ω﻿ for all ω∈Ω.\omega \in \Omega.ω∈Ω.﻿ Then Theorem 2 gives a regular conditional distribution κ\kappaκ﻿ of XXX﻿ given G\mathscr GG﻿ which is precisely a regular version of the conditional probability P(⋅∣G).\mathbb{P}(\cdot \mid \mathscr G).P(⋅∣G).﻿
Suppose in the setting of Definition 6, we also have a measurable space (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr T)(T,T)﻿ and a random element Y ⁣:Ω→T.Y \colon \Omega \to \mathsf T.Y:Ω→T.﻿ Then by the conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given YYY﻿ we will mean the conditional distribution of XXX﻿ given σ(Y).\sigma(Y).σ(Y).﻿
Disintegration
Let us first recall the construction of measures on a product space, which is closely tied with disintegrations. Suppose (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ are measurable spaces, μ\muμ﻿ is a measure on (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿, and κ\kappaκ﻿ is a kernel from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ that can be written as κ=∑n=1∞κn\kappa = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \kappa_nκ=∑n=1∞​κn​﻿ for kernels κn\kappa_nκn​﻿ from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ that satisfy κn(x,T)<∞\kappa_n(x, \mathsf{T}) < \inftyκn​(x,T)<∞﻿ for each x∈Sx \in \mathsf{S}x∈S﻿ (such kernels κ\kappaκ﻿ are called Σ−\Sigma-Σ−﻿finite). If f ⁣:S×T→[−∞,+∞]f \colon \mathsf{S} \times \mathsf{T} \to [-\infty, +\infty]f:S×T→[−∞,+∞]﻿ is measurable, recall that x↦f(x,y)x \mapsto f(x,y)x↦f(x,y)﻿ is measurable for each y∈Ty \in \mathsf Ty∈T﻿ and y↦f(x,y)y \mapsto f(x,y)y↦f(x,y)﻿ is measurable for each x∈S.x \in \mathsf S.x∈S.﻿ If f∈(S⊗T)+f \in (\mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)_+f∈(S⊗T)+​﻿, then
S∋x↦κf(x):=∫Tf(x,y) κ(x,dy)∈[0,+∞]\mathsf S \ni x \mapsto \kappa f(x) := \int_{\mathsf T} f(x,y) \, \kappa(x, \mathrm{d}y) \in [0, +\infty]S∋x↦κf(x):=∫T​f(x,y)κ(x,dy)∈[0,+∞]
defines a non-negative measurable function. The iterated integral
γf≡∫S×Tf dγ:=∫S(∫Tf(x,y) κ(x,dy)) μ(dx)(D1)\gamma f \equiv \int_{\mathsf S \times \mathsf T} f \, \mathrm{d}\gamma := \int_{\mathsf S} \left( \int_{\mathsf T} f(x,y) \, \kappa(x, \mathrm{d}y)\right)\,\mu(\mathrm{d}x) \tag{D1}γf≡∫S×T​fdγ:=∫S​(∫T​f(x,y)κ(x,dy))μ(dx)(D1)
for f∈(S⊗T)+f \in (\mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)_+f∈(S⊗T)+​﻿ defines a measure γ\gammaγ﻿ on the product space (S×T,S⊗T).(\mathsf{S} \times \mathsf T, \mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T).(S×T,S⊗T).﻿ Moreover, if μ\muμ﻿ is σ−\sigma-σ−﻿finite and κ\kappaκ﻿ is σ−\sigma-σ−﻿bounded (i.e., there exists a measurable partition {Tn}\{\mathsf T_n\}{Tn​}﻿ of T\mathsf TT﻿ such that x↦κ(x,Tn)x \mapsto \kappa(x, \mathsf T_n)x↦κ(x,Tn​)﻿ is bounded for each nnn﻿), then γ\gammaγ﻿ is σ−\sigma-σ−﻿finite and is the unique measure on the product space satisfying
γ(A×B)=∫Aκ(x,B) μ(dx),A∈S,B∈T.\gamma(A \times B) = \int_A\kappa(x,B) \, \mu(\mathrm{d} x), \quad A \in \mathscr{S}, B \in \mathscr{T}.γ(A×B)=∫A​κ(x,B)μ(dx),A∈S,B∈T.
We denote γ\gammaγ﻿ with μ⊗κ.\mu \otimes \kappa.μ⊗κ.﻿ For the special case when κ(x,B)=ν(B)\kappa(x,B) = \nu(B)κ(x,B)=ν(B)﻿ for some measure ν\nuν﻿ on T\mathscr TT﻿, like in the example above, we denote γ\gammaγ﻿ with μ⊗ν.\mu \otimes \nu.μ⊗ν.﻿ In this special case we can interchange the order of integrals, i.e.,
∫S(∫Tf(x,y) ν(dy)) μ(dx)=∫T(∫Sf(x,y) μ(dx)) ν(dy),\int_{\mathsf S} \left( \int_{\mathsf T} f(x,y) \, \nu( \mathrm{d}y)\right)\,\mu(\mathrm{d}x) = \int_{\mathsf T} \left( \int_{\mathsf S} f(x,y) \, \mu( \mathrm{d}x)\right)\,\nu(\mathrm{d}y),∫S​(∫T​f(x,y)ν(dy))μ(dx)=∫T​(∫S​f(x,y)μ(dx))ν(dy),
for f∈(S⊗T)+f \in (\mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)_+f∈(S⊗T)+​﻿ (this is known as the Tonelli’s theorem). Also if f ⁣:S×T→[−∞,+∞]f \colon \mathsf{S} \times \mathsf{T} \to [-\infty, +\infty]f:S×T→[−∞,+∞]﻿ is μ⊗ν−\mu \otimes \nu-μ⊗ν−﻿integrable, then x↦f(x,y)x \mapsto f(x,y)x↦f(x,y)﻿ is μ−\mu-μ−﻿integrable for ν−\nu-ν−﻿a.e. yyy﻿, and y↦f(x,y)y \mapsto f(x,y)y↦f(x,y)﻿ is ν−\nu-ν−﻿integrable for μ−\mu-μ−﻿a.e. xxx﻿, and the interchange above holds again (this is known as the Fubini’s theorem).
Disintegration asks the converse to the construction of measures on product spaces: Given a measure γ\gammaγ﻿ on the product space (S×T,S⊗T)(\mathsf{S} \times \mathsf T, \mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)(S×T,S⊗T)﻿ does there exist a measure μ\muμ﻿ on (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and a kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ such that (D1)\text{(D1)}(D1)﻿ holds? We will answer in this in the affirmative for the special case for probability measures and stochastic kernels. For a more thorough discussion see the paper Conditioning as disintegration by Chang and Pollard [5].
Theorem 3: Suppose (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ are measurable spaces with (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr T)(T,T)﻿ being a standard Borel space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra, and γ\gammaγ﻿ is a probability measure on the product space (S×T,S⊗T).(\mathsf{S} \times \mathsf T, \mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T).(S×T,S⊗T).﻿ Then there exists a probability measure μ\muμ﻿ on (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and a stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ such that (D1)\text{(D1)}(D1)﻿ holds for all f∈(S⊗T)+.f \in (\mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)_+.f∈(S⊗T)+​.﻿
Proof: [From Cinlar Theorem IV.2.18 [3]]

Now a natural question is if μ\muμ﻿ is a probability measure, corresponding to the law of a random variable Y ⁣:Ω→S,Y \colon \Omega \to \mathsf S,Y:Ω→S,﻿ and κ\kappaκ﻿ is a stochastic kernel, such that the product measure μ⊗κ\mu \otimes \kappaμ⊗κ﻿ corresponds to the law of a random vector (Y,X) ⁣:Ω→S×T,(Y, X) \colon \Omega \to \mathsf{S} \times \mathsf T,(Y,X):Ω→S×T,﻿ with X ⁣:Ω→TX \colon \Omega \to \mathsf TX:Ω→T﻿ being some random variable, can we associate κ\kappaκ﻿ with the conditional distribution for XXX﻿ given Y?Y?Y?﻿ The next theorem answers this question.
Theorem 4: Suppose (Ω,F,P)(\Omega, \mathscr F, \mathbb P)(Ω,F,P)﻿ is a probability space, (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ and (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T})(T,T)﻿ are measurable spaces, and Y ⁣:Ω→SY \colon \Omega \to \mathsf SY:Ω→S﻿ and X ⁣:Ω→TX \colon \Omega \to \mathsf TX:Ω→T﻿ are random elements such that the law of YYY﻿ is μ\muμ﻿ and the law of (Y,X)(Y, X)(Y,X)﻿ is μ⊗κ\mu \otimes \kappaμ⊗κ﻿ for a stochastic kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (T,T).(\mathsf T, \mathscr{T}).(T,T).﻿ Denote G=σ(Y).\mathscr G = \sigma(Y).G=σ(Y).﻿ Then the stochastic kernel η\etaη﻿ from (Ω,G)(\Omega, \mathscr{G})(Ω,G)﻿ to (T,T)(\mathsf T, \mathscr T)(T,T)﻿ defined by

Proof:

To see (D2)\text{(D2)}(D2)﻿, note that for B∈T,B \in \mathscr T,B∈T,﻿ property (R1)\text{(R1)}(R1)﻿ for η\etaη﻿ says
η(B)=P({X∈B}∣G) a.s..\eta(B) = \mathbb{P}(\{X \in B\} \mid \mathscr G) \text{ a.s.}.η(B)=P({X∈B}∣G) a.s..

Although we won’t be needing it, let me briefly mention the notion of generalized disintegration.
Definition 7: Let (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr E)(E,E)﻿ and (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ be measurable spaces, S ⁣:E→SS \colon \mathsf E \to \mathsf SS:E→S﻿ be a measurable mapping, γ\gammaγ﻿ be a measure on (E,E),(\mathsf E, \mathscr E),(E,E),﻿ and μ\muμ﻿ be a measure on (S,S).(\mathsf S, \mathscr S).(S,S).﻿ We call a kernel κ\kappaκ﻿ from (S,S)(\mathsf S, \mathscr{S})(S,S)﻿ to (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr{E})(E,E)﻿ a (S,μ)−(S, \mu)-(S,μ)−﻿disintegration of γ\gammaγ﻿ if
κx{S≠x}=0\kappa_x\{S \neq x\} = 0κx​{S=x}=0﻿ for μ−\mu-μ−﻿a.e. xxx﻿, and
we have the following iterated integral for each measurable f ⁣:E→[0,∞]f \colon \mathsf E \to [0, \infty]f:E→[0,∞]﻿
∫Ef dγ=∫S(∫Ef(y) κx(dy))μ(dx).(D3)\int_{\mathsf E} f \, \mathrm{d}\gamma = \int_{\mathsf S} \left( \int_{\mathsf E} f(y) \,\kappa_x(\mathrm{d}y) \right) \mu(\mathrm{d}x). \tag{D3}∫E​fdγ=∫S​(∫E​f(y)κx​(dy))μ(dx).(D3)
Note that, because of property 1, we can write (D3)\text{(D3)}(D3)﻿ as
∫Ef dγ=∫S(∫{S=x}f(y) κx(dy))μ(dx).(D3)\int_{\mathsf E} f \, \mathrm{d}\gamma = \int_{\mathsf S} \left( \int_{\{S=x\}} f(y) \,\kappa_x(\mathrm{d}y) \right) \mu(\mathrm{d}x). \tag{D3}∫E​fdγ=∫S​(∫{S=x}​f(y)κx​(dy))μ(dx).(D3)
The disintegration discussed in Theorem 3 is a special case of the disintegration discussed in Definition 7. To see this, let (E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr E)(E,E)﻿ be the product space (S×T,S⊗T)(\mathsf{S} \times \mathsf T, \mathscr S \otimes \mathscr T)(S×T,S⊗T)﻿ and S ⁣:S×T→SS \colon \mathsf S \times \mathsf T \to \mathsf SS:S×T→S﻿ be the canonical projection. {S=x}\{S = x\}{S=x}﻿ is then simply T\mathsf TT﻿ and equation (D3)\text{(D3)}(D3)﻿ becomes equation (D1).\text{(D1)}.(D1).﻿
The following existence theorem is taken from Pollard’s book [4].
Theorem 5: Under the setting of Definition 7, assume that
(E,E)(\mathsf E, \mathscr E)(E,E)﻿ is a metric space endowed with its Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra,
γ\gammaγ﻿ and μ\muμ﻿ are σ−\sigma-σ−﻿finite with γ\gammaγ﻿ being a Radon measure (i.e., γ(K)<∞\gamma(K) < \inftyγ(K)<∞﻿ for each compact KKK﻿ and γ(B)=sup⁡K⊆Bγ(K),\gamma(B) = \sup_{K \subseteq B} \gamma(K),γ(B)=supK⊆B​γ(K),﻿ the supremum being taken over compact sets, for each B∈EB \in\mathscr EB∈E﻿),
the image measure γ∘S−1\gamma \circ S^{-1}γ∘S−1﻿ of γ\gammaγ﻿ under SSS﻿ is absolutely continuous with respect to μ,\mu,μ,﻿ and
the graph ⟦S⟧:={(y,x)∈(E,S):S(y)=x}\llbracket S \rrbracket := \{(y,x) \in (\mathsf E, \mathsf S) : S(y) = x\}[[S]]:={(y,x)∈(E,S):S(y)=x}﻿ is contained in the product σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra E⊗S.\mathscr E \otimes \mathscr S.E⊗S.﻿
Then γ\gammaγ﻿ has a (S,μ)−(S, \mu)-(S,μ)−﻿disintegration κ\kappaκ﻿, unique up to a μ−\mu-μ−﻿equivalence, in the sense that if κ‾\overline \kappaκ﻿ is another (S,μ)−(S, \mu)-(S,μ)−﻿disintegration, then μ{x∈S:κx≠κ‾x}=0.\mu\{x \in \mathsf S : \kappa_x \neq \overline\kappa_x\} = 0.μ{x∈S:κx​=κx​}=0.﻿
As an example of a Radon measure, every σ−\sigma-σ−﻿finite measure on the Borel σ−\sigma-σ−﻿algebra of a Polish space which assigns finite measure to compact sets is Radon.
